author: Mohammed Iqbal
text:
: The Delhi High Court has reserved its judgment on a batch of writ petitions seeking lifting of the ban on the BBC documentary film, “India’s Daughter”, based on the theme of the December 16, 2012, gangrape, while observing that the matter was pending before the trial court.

A Division Bench comprising Chief Justice G. Rohini and Justice Jayant Nath, reserving the verdict earlier this week, asked if it was right to keep the matter pending when the matter was before the trial court. The petitioners could bring the issue to the notice of the trial court, said the Bench.

Three law students had filed the petitions seeking lifting of the ban on the documentary, saying it had revealed the mindset of one of the convicted rapists.

One of the petitioners pointed out that the trial court had passed an order regarding ban on the documentary film only on the basis of a first information report.

The court had earlier asked the purpose the ban on the documentary served when it was available on internet and had directed the police to state the legal provisions under which the prohibition was imposed.

The documentary was produced by British film-maker Leslee Udwin and telecast by British Broadcasting Corporation.
title: Verdict reserved on pleas against ban on gangrape documentary
